title: 108_s1880
content: The Act is titled the "Special Blue Ribbon Commission on Chesapeake Bay Nutrient Pollution Control Financing Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act establishes a commission to develop a plan to remove the Chesapeake Bay from the EPA's impaired waterways list by 2010, reduce sediment and nutrient loadings, identify financial resources, and establish partnerships for the effort. The Special Blue Ribbon Commission on Chesapeake Bay Nutrient Pollution Control Financing is established by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency with 21 members, including signatories to the Chesapeake Bay Agreement, governors of Delaware, New York, and West Virginia, and 12 members appointed by the Administrator. The Executive Council of the Chesapeake Bay program includes members representing local governments in Maryland, Pennsylvania, and Virginia, as well as members from academic, business, agricultural, and environmental sectors. The council's composition is balanced by area of expertise. The Commission members are balanced by expertise and geography. The Chairperson is elected from the members. Meetings are called by the Chairperson and open to the public. Notice of meetings is published in media outlets. Minutes are kept for all meetings. The initial meeting must occur within 30 days. The Commission must hold an initial meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Additionally, the Commission is required to hold meetings in Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania. SEC. 4. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with developing a comprehensive plan to reduce nutrient pollution in the Chesapeake Bay by 2010, addressing funding needs and responsibilities of various government levels for sewage treatment upgrades, runoff controls, and stormwater management. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within one year of its establishment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for administrative and legislative actions at all government levels to implement a comprehensive plan to restore the water quality of the Chesapeake Bay. The Commission will submit a report detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for actions to restore the water quality of the Chesapeake Bay. Before submitting the report, a notice will be published for public review and comment on a draft report. The Commission will submit a report with findings and recommendations to restore Chesapeake Bay's water quality. SEC. 5 outlines the powers granted to the Commission. The Commission may obtain necessary information from Federal agencies and establish a science and technical advisory panel to assist in carrying out its duties related to water quality improvement in Chesapeake Bay. The Commission may enter into contracts and appoint necessary personnel to carry out its duties, ensuring scientific information is based on the best available data. Confirmation of executive director's employment is subject to Commission's approval. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report under section 4(b)(1).
